overview_summary: All five profiled neighbors have no clearly documented stance on the development, as none are on record supporting or opposing it. None hold public office, with one medium-influence neighbor (a local business owner) and the rest being private landowners with low community influence.

neighbors.name: Albert and Donnarae Wines
neighbors.claims: Albert and Donnarae Wines jointly own two parcels of land in Berrien County, Michigan ([www.berriencounty.org](https://www.berriencounty.org/877/Property-Tax-Tools?PREVIEW=YES#:~:text=1,Property%20Tax%20Estimator)). No record of either Albert or Donnarae taking part in local government meetings or making public comments on development was found ([www.weesawtownship.net](https://www.weesawtownship.net/township-board#:~:text=Township%20Administration)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a trusted local acquaintance introduce the project, emphasizing respect for their land and reassuring that the development won’t disrupt their way of life. Personal outreach through a neighborly conversation may resonate given their low public profile.

neighbors.name: Edward E. Weaver Sr.
neighbors.claims: Edward E. Weaver Sr. is identified as the owner of a parcel in Berrien County (PIN 11-22-0011-0027-00-3) according to county land records ([www.berriencounty.org](https://www.berriencounty.org/877/Property-Tax-Tools?PREVIEW=YES#:~:text=1,Property%20Tax%20Estimator)). His name does not appear in township board listings or local news, indicating no noted civic position or public stance on development ([www.weesawtownship.net](https://www.weesawtownship.net/township-board#:~:text=Township%20Administration)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Mr. Weaver through a one-on-one conversation, possibly via a long-time community member he trusts. Providing clear, straightforward information about the project and listening to any concerns can build rapport given his lack of public involvement.

neighbors.name: William A. and Frances S. Krumrie
neighbors.claims: William A. Krumrie and Frances S. Krumrie jointly own multiple parcels of property in the county (two identified by the given PINs) ([www.berriencounty.org](https://www.berriencounty.org/877/Property-Tax-Tools?PREVIEW=YES#:~:text=1,Property%20Tax%20Estimator)). There are no public records of the Krumries in any official township roles or speaking out on local development issues ([www.weesawtownship.net](https://www.weesawtownship.net/township-board#:~:text=Township%20Administration)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Krumries through a mutual local contact (e.g., a farming neighbor or community friend). Emphasize that the project will respect land use norms and address any practical concerns, which may appeal to their quiet presence in the community.

neighbors.name: Alex Nakonechny
neighbors.claims: Alex Nakonechny appears to have real estate interests beyond the area; he is listed as an owner on several building permits in Chicago ([www.chicagocityscape.com](https://www.chicagocityscape.com/companies.php?company=Alex+Nakonechny#:~:text=Alex%20Nakonechny%20is%20listed%20on,Chicago%20building%20permits%20as%20Owner)). No record was found of Nakonechny engaging in local civic affairs or voicing opinions on development in township records ([www.weesawtownship.net](https://www.weesawtownship.net/township-board#:~:text=Township%20Administration)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight the project’s potential to maintain or enhance property values and any long-term financial benefits. Given his investor background, framing the discussion in terms of economic opportunity and minimal risk to his assets could be effective.

neighbors.name: Gail Hanchar
neighbors.claims: Gail Hanchar is a local entrepreneur who opened and expanded the Crumb Crossing Bakery in downtown Niles in 2014–2015 ([www.leaderpub.com](https://www.leaderpub.com/2015/04/01/crumb-crossing-bakery-moves-re-opens-with-full-menu/#:~:text=Five%20months%20after%20opening%20a,Main%20St)). She has expressed enthusiasm for community events, noting she was “blown away” by the large crowds during a local festival that benefited her business ([www.leaderpub.com](https://www.leaderpub.com/2015/01/20/niles-businesses-report-successful-hunter-ice-fest/#:~:text=Gail%20Hanchar%2C%20owner%20of%20new,Festival%20as%20a%20business%20owner)). No public position by Hanchar on development or energy projects has been documented in media or records as of this date ([www.weesawtownship.net](https://www.weesawtownship.net/township-board#:~:text=Township%20Administration)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected figure from the local business community reach out to her. Emphasize how the development could positively impact the local economy or community events, aligning with her evident enthusiasm for initiatives that draw people and boost downtown activity.
